entry.title: Game: Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance (PS3, 2013) (11)
entry.content:
Game: Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance (PS3, 2013) (11)20130307
I played this afternoon for an hour and a half. I mainly did VR
Missions. I did everything up to 17. After that I tried each and
said "It's not worth it" and stop. I almost gave up at 13 because
the sliders were so unforgiving, but once I used the Sai and
aerial attacks exclusively it was reasonable. 14 was really hard
too, because it seemed like you to go in the perfect order. 15
and 16 were really dumb. 15 was a waypoint where you run forward
and get knocked back by RPGs and then 16 was "stand-in-place and
shoot a turret". The VR Missions in general feel pretty
un-inspired and tedious to do... and even more tedious to try and
do 1st place on. Maybe it would be a bit easier to swallow if the
reload times weren't so bad.

With that, I'm done with the game. It was very enjoyable and the
combat system was pretty original and fun. I thought the story
was a fun little Metal Gear side-story: it doesn't really move
the whole universe forward, but it feels like it takes place in
the same place, which is cool. I don't think the game's combat
was as deep as Bayonetta or Vanquish, but it was unique and fun
in its own way. I'd definitely play it again in the future, but I
don't feel like I need to 100% it anymore.

entry.content:
Book: Elantris, by Brandon Sanderson (2005) (4)20130228
I read seven chapters today.

Compare: "Hrathen would ever bear the scars of what he had done,
but it was better that one man suffer than an entire nation
continue in heresy." (Elantris, p203) vs "Behold the Lord slayeth
the wicked to bring forth his righteous purposes. It is better that
one man should perish than that a nation should dwindle and perish
in unbelief." (1 Nephi 4:13)

Given that I know what will happen in the end, it is exciting to
see the foreshadowing (and foreboding) about the deadly monks of
the East. It's very cool.

Another way to look at what Raoden is doing in Elantris: Since he
giving everyone something to do and their lack of anything to do
was making them miserable, in a sense he is saying that if you (a)
live forever, (b) don't change/grow, and (c) don't have anything to
do, then you will be miserable. This is interesting from a *REDACTED*
perspective, because that describes perfectly what non-*REDACTED*
Heaven is like, whereas in the *REDACTED* concept of Heaven, everyone
has purpose and growth, and thus, according to /Elantris/,
happiness.

I really enjoyed how Raoden "converted" Taan with love and
reminding him of the beauty of the world.

entry.content:
Book: Elantris, by Brandon Sanderson (2005) (3)20130227
I read two more chapters.

I like the discussion of the holy language of Jaddeth and where
converts should have to learn it. I think there's something similar
in *REDACTED*ism and English because all translations have to made from
English because the source of the Book of *REDACTED* is not available.

I like the discussion of using the Seons in Jaddeth's empire. It
is reminiscent to me of Islamic fundamentalists using technology
for their military purposes, yet claiming that technology designed
for improving people's lives is immoral.

I like that when Raoden meets with Karata the revelation is that
children are the greatest happiness in life and all toil is worth
it if you can take care of them.

My wife had the brilliant idea to see each of the characters as a
different model of leadership. Raoden has optimism and can give
people hope, by putting them to productive ends. Hrathen and
Sarene are both calculating and political, but I think they
represent those skills being put towards bad and good ends, so
they are interesting exemplars.

I'm mastering the game a lot more... I've discovered that when you
are cutting off left arms, it is best to aim yourself, but when

There's lots of stuff I'm clearly missing, because I will get VR

This game is still great.

--

In the evening I played for about three hours. I played through
the rest of outside the tower and then the inside, so I fought the
Sundowner guy, who has seemed like the big bad most of the
time. In the fight outside the tower with Monsoon, I finally got

The fight with Sundowner was intense, but I think I did it the

I'm a bit surprised that the child-soldier-brain-extraction thing

I'm starting to complete some of the upgrade trees, I wonder if

The opening of the next chapter was pretty nuts... jumping out of

entry.title: Book: Elantris, by Brandon Sanderson (2005) (2)
entry.content:
Book: Elantris, by Brandon Sanderson (2005) (2)20130224
I read quite a few more chapters today and having a smattering of
thoughts.

- The contrast between Dilaf's zealotry and Hrathen's practicality
is very interesting. For example, Dilaf says something like
"Nothing can stand in Jaddeth's way" as an argument against why
they should do some plan for the Kae. Hrathen's response is,
"Then why isn't the whole world converted?" One idea I can see in
this is that often the "sophisticated theology" of the
upper-class of religionists make them have almost totally
different beliefs than the lower-class, to the point that the
upper-class may not even seem like they believe at all. I get
this impression about *REDACTED*ism a lot when people talk about how
to treat new converts, especially those in far away places.

- Hrathen gives a very *REDACTED* explanation of the Svarkiss: "Nothing
is more bitter than a soul who had had its chance and thrown it
away." This is the way that Satan and his followers are discussed
a lot in *REDACTED*ism and how many ex-members are seen.

- A poignant moment in one of Raoden's chapters is the discussion
of how Elantris was not built for normal people to live
in---there are no wells or furnances or lights---and that after
the fall of AonDor it is totally desolate. How is this related to
Modern worry about a too heavy reliance on technology and the
desire to train ourselves to live without in times of disaster?

- I like that Sarene's plan to change the government is so
libertarian and capitalistic. You can almost see the debate on
what to do as a debate about how to intervene in communist
countries and/or get them to change for the better. Freedom
works.
